original_question: When does coal release most of its energy?

pred_ans: Coal releases most of its energy when it is burned.
pred_ans_conf_MCQ: Coal releases most of its energy when it is burned
pred_diverse_ans: Coal releases the majority of its energy when it is burned at high temperatures in a process called combustion.
Coal typically discharges its maximum energy when it is burned at high temperatures in a power plant.
The energy emission from coal is at its peak when it is burning.
The maximum release of energy from coal is usually experienced during combustion, which occurs when coal is burned in the presence of oxygen.
Coal tends to give off its highest energy when it is burning at its hottest temperature, which is typically around 2000 degrees Fahrenheit.
The majority of energy emission from coal occurs during combustion.
Coal usually emits its peak energy during combustion, which occurs when it is heated to high temperatures in the presence of oxygen.
The most substantial energy release from coal is during combustion, which occurs when coal is burned in the presence of oxygen.
